data.title: UK radio callsigns
data.meta_description: Hi all, I was just thinking, if UK radio stations adopted the same callsign naming system as countries like the US and Canada, what would radio stations here have been called?
data.text:
The original stations that became the BBC had names like 2LO (London), 2BM (Bournemouth) etc. They'd probably be the same sort of think now, certainly the successor to 2LO (which is probably either what is now 5live or Talk SPort from Brookmans Park) would be called that.

With our system of network radio stations rather than lots of individual licenses it wouldn't be workable

0

The original stations that became the BBC had names like 2LO (London), 2BM (Bournemouth) etc. They'd probably be the same sort of think now, certainly the successor to 2LO (which is probably either what is now 5live or Talk SPort from Brookmans Park) would be called that.

With our system of network radio stations rather than lots of individual licenses it wouldn't be workable

Australia still uses this system for its AM stations with the number denoting the state ...2 is NSW;3 is Victoria; 5 is SA; 6 is WA etc. thus 6PR in Perth WA; 2UE in Sydney, NSW; 3UZ in Melbourne, Vic; 5AD in Adelaide, SA for example. I believe the FM staions have 3 letters such as the famous Triple J.

There have been examples of UK stations emulating American call letters - BRMB and WABC in the West Midlands spring to mind.

And was there not a fort based 60's pirate which called itself Britain's Better Music Station aka BBMS

0

There have been examples of UK stations emulating American call letters - BRMB and WABC in the West Midlands spring to mind.

And was there not a fort based 60's pirate which called itself Britain's Better Music Station aka BBMS

Which makes me wonder if it would be legal under ITU for a MW station in the UK to emulate call signs from other countries.

I can see some North American scratching his head one evening if the frequency comes close to *0 Khz.

I read somewhere once Aussie stations sometimes make up a call sign even though they have one assigned to them.

0

2CR name originally came from 'Two Counties Radio" and wasn't a call sign that the licensing authority issued.

American stations used their call signs as there were so many stations that interference was often caused and something distinct was necessary to identify which stations was which - regular names only would not have sufficed. Many 'heritage' calls did opaquely refer to the stations though - like the station in Chicago owned by a newspaper which was WGN - Worlds Greatest Newspaper, and is still all news today. Same city has WLS 0n 890 AM which was owned by Sears, the Worlds Largest Store.

The Uk had nothing like the interference problems, and I dare say the pedestrian style of presentation and frequent long breaks in transmission, not to mention the ID "This is the BBC" meant there was rarely any confusion, so no need for call signs. They could not be mandatory, as there is no global licensing authority. The ITU is a talking shop and international 'treaty' body with no bite or power at all beyond that which each state deems to confer on it.

The US FCC still insists on regular station IDs, something the UK doesn't bother with.

0
